questions.title: I take pride in being seen as reliable and ready for any circumstance.
I base my self-worth on being accepted by others, forgetting that I must accept myself first.
I have difficulty with emotional intimacy and fear being vulnerable, leading me to thrive on independence.
I struggle to set healthy boundaries for myself while being accommodating to others.
I experience feelings of guilt when I believe that I have made a mistake.
I hold onto partners, friends, and family members who negatively impact my well-being and leave me feeling exhausted.
I see rest as a waste of time, as it will not contribute to my progress or advancement.
I compare and measure my current situation against an ideal one.
I frequently make justifications for why things should remain unchanged.
I think that by excessively caring for others, I am boosting my own sense of self-worth.
I engage in behaviors that are not in my best interest to maintain high levels of enthusiasm.
I engage in self-gratifying behaviors like binge-watching TV, overeating, staying out late on workdays, spending money I should save, etc.
I find validation in making others happy, even though I am aware that it's driven by feelings of obligation and guilt.
I believe that the hardest workers are always appreciated.
By taking on the problems of others, I feel valued and unique.
I focus on negative self-talk and silence positive assumptions.
I am strongly committed to achieving perfection in all my endeavors.
I seek validation by portraying myself as a noble sufferer.
I believe that the circumstances in my life are outside of my control, and that I am a victim of them.
I cultivate the need for others to be dependent upon me and I make sure they are aware of it.
I believe that it's not appropriate to display negative emotions.
I am critical of myself when I don't complete tasks.
I believe that if I don't help others, it means I don't care about or love them
I am responsible for the negative emotions people close to me experience
I have a tendency to focus on worst-case scenarios.
I cannot be happy in the present moment, because I believe that happiness comes with achievement, and my achievements are never enough
I am prepared for crises as I anticipate them in advance.
I overemphasize practical issues and often neglect my dreams.
I provide comfort to myself and others by articulating idealized perspectives.
It is common for me to feel envy and jealousy about the success of others.
I think that my personal worth and value are directly linked to the amount of work and accomplishments I achieve.
I am inclined to scrutinize the intentions of others.
I am confident that I can manage anything, as long as I work hard, supervise, and maintain control.
I focus on potential risks and the negative aspects of a circumstance, forgetting to consider the possible benefits
Material possessions are not a priority for me.
I often compare myself to others and feel inadequate in my own abilities.
I have faith that if I keep pushing, things will eventually improve.
I tend to think that if I experience sadness, I must have some kind of flaw or issue.
I believe that everything nice has an expiration date.
I maintain emotional barriers that keep others at a distance, which I believe will protect me from getting hurt.
